thread.title: St. Francis football struggles in shootout
thread.title_full: St. Francis football struggles in shootout

title: St. Francis football struggles in shootout
text:
St. Francis football struggles in shootout Published: Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015 12:08 a.m. CDT By KEVIN BEESE editorial@kcchronicle.com 
WHEATON – The St. Francis football team had no answer for St. Laurence’s high-powered offense Friday night, giving up 447 yards in a 49-35 shootout loss. 
In a Chicago Catholic League crossover game, the Vikings outscored St. Francis, 28-7, in the second half to come away with the victory. 
Vikings junior running back Fayezon Smart ran for 248 yards and four touchdowns in the victory.St. Francis’ Nolan Pechan did his best to match Smart’s performance, running for 179 yards and four touchdowns himself in a game that saw just one punt between the two teams. 
Two Spartans drives were stopped when St. Laurence’s Jimmy Burnette intercepted St. Francis quarterback Peter Fassnacht, once in the end zone. 
Pechan scored from 1, 2 and 10 yards out in the first half to put the Spartans up 28-21 at the break. He added a 2-yard touchdown run with 3:27 left in the third quarter for the Spartans’ only second-half points. 
In a game where both offenses went no-huddle and marched up and down the field almost at will in the first half, it looked like whatever team had the ball last might come away with the victory. 
However, the Spartans (4-2) couldn’t keep pace, turning the ball over on downs on both of their fourth-quarter possessions. 
The Spartan offense was firing on all cylinders, running 45 plays in the first half and scoring on four of its five possessions. Fassnacht was 14 for 20 passing for 180 yards in the first half. His completions included a 13-yard touchdown pass to tight end Brent Whelton,. 
However, in the second half, Fassnacht was just 6 for 13 for 70 yards and one interception. Half of his second-half passing yards came on one fourth-quarter toss to Whelton. 
The Spartans clung to a seven-point lead at halftime when Viking receiver Alec Freeman scampered 42 yards as time expired but was ruled down inside the 1-yard line when he dove for the end zone at the end of the run. St. Laurence (4-2) argued the call, but to no avail.
